etymologies: late Old English, from Old Norse rás ‘current’. It was originally a northern English word with the sense ‘rapid forward movement’, which gave rise to the senses ‘contest of speed’ (early 16th century) and ‘channel, path’ (i.e. the space traversed). The verb dates from the late 15th century

definitions: a competition between runners, horses, vehicles, boats, etc., to see which is the fastest in covering a set course

examples.text: I won the first 50-lap race

shortDefinitions: competition between runners, horses, or vehicles

definitions: a series of races for horses or dogs, held at a fixed time on a set course.
shortDefinitions: series of such competitions for horses or dogs

definitions: a situation in which individuals or groups compete to be first to achieve a particular objective

examples.text: the race for nuclear power

shortDefinitions: competition to achieve objective

definitions: the course of the sun or moon through the heavens

examples.text: the industrious sun already half his race hath run

shortDefinitions: course of sun or moon through heavens

definitions: a strong or rapid current flowing through a narrow channel in the sea or a river

examples.text: angling for tuna in turbulent tidal races

shortDefinitions: strong or rapid current flowing through narrow channel in sea

definitions: a water channel, especially one built to lead water to or from a point where its energy is utilized, as in a mill or mine.
shortDefinitions: water channel

definitions: a smooth ring-shaped groove or guide in which a ball bearing or roller bearing runs.
shortDefinitions: ring-shaped groove or guide

definitions: compete with another or others to see who is fastest at covering a set course or achieving an objective

examples.text: the vet took blood samples from the horses before they raced
attorneys have to think twice before they race each other to the courthouse

shortDefinitions: compete with another or others to see who is fastest at covering set course or achieving objective

definitions: compete regularly in races as a sport or leisure activity

examples.text: the next year, he raced again for the team

shortDefinitions: compete regularly in races as sport or leisure activity

definitions: prepare and enter (an animal or vehicle) in races as a sport or leisure activity

examples.text: he raced his three horses simply for the fun of it

shortDefinitions: prepare and enter animal or vehicle for races

definitions: move or progress swiftly or at full speed

examples.text: I raced into the house
she spoke automatically, while her mind raced ahead

shortDefinitions: move or progress swiftly or at full speed

definitions: operate or cause to operate at excessive speed

examples.text: she'd driven like a madwoman, racing the engine and swerving around corners

shortDefinitions: operate or cause to operate at excessive speed

definitions: (of a person's heart or pulse) beat faster than usual because of fear or excitement.
shortDefinitions: (of person's heart or pulse) beat faster than usual because of fear or excitement

etymologies: early 16th century (denoting a group with common features): via French from Italian razza, of unknown ultimate origin

notes.text: In recent years, the associations of race with the ideologies and theories that grew out of the work of 19th-century anthropologists and physiologists has led to the use of the word race itself becoming problematic. Although still used in general contexts, it is now often replaced by other words which are less emotionally charged, such as people(s) or community

definitions: each of the major groupings into which humankind is considered (in various theories or contexts) to be divided on the basis of physical characteristics or shared ancestry

examples.text: people of all races, colors, and creeds

notes.text: Although ideas of race are centuries old, it was not until the 19th century that attempts to systematize racial divisions were made. Ideas of supposed racial superiority and social Darwinism reached their culmination in Nazi ideology of the 1930s and gave pseudoscientific justification to policies and attitudes of discrimination, exploitation, slavery, and extermination. Theories of race asserting a link between racial type and intelligence are now discredited. Scientifically it is accepted as obvious that there are subdivisions of the human species, but it is also clear that genetic variation between individuals of the same race can be as great as that between members of different races

shortDefinitions: major grouping into which humankind is considered to be divided

definitions: the fact or condition of belonging to a racial division or group, or the qualities or characteristics associated with this

examples.text: people of mixed race
issues of race and national identity

shortDefinitions: fact or condition of belonging to racial division or group

definitions: a group of people sharing the same culture, history, language, etc.; an ethnic group

examples.text: we Scots were a bloodthirsty race then

shortDefinitions: group of people sharing same culture

definitions: a group or set of people or things with a common feature or features

examples.text: the upper classes thought of themselves as a race apart

shortDefinitions: group or set of people or things with common feature

definitions: a population within a species that is distinct in some way, especially a subspecies

examples.text: people have killed so many tigers that two races are probably extinct

shortDefinitions: population within species that is distinct in some way

definitions: (in nontechnical use) each of the major divisions of living creatures

examples.text: a member of the human race
the race of birds

shortDefinitions: each of major divisions of living creatures

definitions: a group of people descended from a common ancestor

examples.text: a prince of the race of Solomon

shortDefinitions: group of people descended from common ancestor

definitions: ancestry

examples.text: two coursers of ethereal race

shortDefinitions: ancestry

etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French rais, from Latin radix, radic- ‘root’

definitions: a ginger root.
shortDefinitions: ginger root
